Dylan,

We are experiencing issues with the punch operations for one specific file. The machine is running the file fine until it reaches a point where multiple lip cut operations have been modeled in and it pausing at this operation with no errors on the machine. The hydraulic system appears to stay pressurized, as if the machine is still trying to complete a punch op, but no errors pop up and we are forced to use the E-stop and then completely shut down the machine to reset it. The machine is not recognizing the E-stop on the controller when this happens. If we do not restart the machine, the hydraulic system repressurizes once the E-stop is no longer depressed, which is why we are having to completely shut off the power to restart the machine.
Please follow up with
@j.catron@mark-three.com
who is our machine operator, he is CC’ed on this email. If you could hop on a call with him at your next available appointment, we would greatly appreciate it.
Thank you

This one is waiting on an updated electrical schematic because the way the hydraulic drive signal works got changed in between versions.
Print pump is not working, has 24v at the controller but not at the pump itself.
On site to service and carry out training
Can not clear the fault
New punches have been fitted and broke on first punch. -flange hole and dimple punches.
I asked to go through the fitting of the punches.
Error wont allow machine to open Howick HLC
I can get matt to send a TeamViewer code at 8pm Sunday night GMT (9am Monday morning NZT)
initial request made by Wernick staff to provide remote support to improve the profile and reduce bell-mouthing to floor joists.
images where received and support given to initially improve the lip size and adjust the infeed guide this improved the profile and a roller hight check was also undertaken.
currently the images show some over-forming of the profile so adjustments are being made to correct this and square the flanges on the profile.
I will update as i receive information back from site.
Report received of profile out of square and punch tools failing to cut and causing waste material to jam.
on investigation supporting the machine operator the infeed and chain guides were adjusted to correct the lip size and this has improved the profile.
investigating the punch issues I requested a coil check and i was sent a coil cert that notes the coil thickness as 2.88mm a gauge check sent by the operator is showing 2.95mm.

I have messaged CPAC group chat with this information and raised my concerns regarding this material being run through the machine and the consequences of trying to process with this material being 1.5mm thicker gauge than the machine is specified for.
Method to find fault
Ran 1200 test square CSV until run-on pop-up appeared as normal.
Selected ‘Load More’ and loaded 5 additional 1200 test square CSV’s. These files were loaded one at at time by selecting the plus icon.
Ran these panels and Run-On appeared during the first of the 5 additional squares loaded rather than during the last panel as expected.

Ran a further test with the 1200 test square loaded first. At run-on 3 of addition Truss comissioning test CSV’s were loaded. Again, Run-On appeared during the first panel loaded rather than the final panel.
Will need to test this situation on 6.1.
Settings Warning every time the machine is set to Automatic or on start-up. Lip cut faults when operating manually however all other tools function.
Machine rolls forward and back, Punches all tools but lip cuts in manual.
Machine has been power cycled multiple times.
Roller block on one side of lip roller has worn out and shaft fallen out.
The below was tested on HLC Version 6.0.153.
A SHEAR operation was added to the CSV file attached at 4500mm.
When run, this component with the SHEAR operation @4500mm was cut 300mm short. The shear at the end of the component was in the incorrect place.
This problem was able to recreated by running the CSV File again.
When the SHEAR operation @4500mm was removed, there was no issues with incorrect punch positions.
Note: This file was also tested on HLC Version 6.2.0.7. On this HLC Version the file could not be loaded, an error message appeared that the SHEAR tool did not exist (as long as the setting
Can Assign to Component
is off).

We do however have another problem. We are loading up the frames as normal, the machine runs a couple of lengths off, as normal, and then the guillotine fails to cut,  the machine keeps running, no other punches fire it just keeps running and we have to e-stop, but no error messages come up.
So currently we are unable to roll.
Send the customer a license response and he got the following error loading it to the machine.

Operator kept getting decoiler error. Checked that the machine was reset and that the decoiler drive was in ready mode, then I had the operator chart the inclometer arm in the diagnostic page while raising the arm; the chart did not move. They need a replacement inclometer.
Shear dropping off proximity.
Asked them to clean the check valve.
We are wanting to connect the machine computer to our network so we can access files directly from the machine, how do we go about achieving this?
Cheers, Matt.

Right hand printer not working.
no ink or solvent from head when printing or purging.
system checks carried out by operator and after repeated purging with solvent they cleared the line and swapped to ink.
the printer is now functioning and in a follow up call the issue is resolved.
Call Support with Merit after repeated faulting on the 250mm profile block notch tool not returning to home position during cycle.
After carrying out a number of tests and checks trying to identify the cause of the problem these included
Oil level check
proximity sensor check and replacement.
Check punch tool bolts were tight accessing from under the block.
broken return spring check, no damage reported and then replacement with new spares.
Block alignment check.
replaced quick release coupling with fitting from another pre punch block.
removed oil filter from tank and replaced after testing.
None of the above checks cleared the fault so the block was removed and stripped down and inspected for damage, no scoring or marking was found on the tool or the block plates.
the notch tool was rotated while re-building the block and fitted back to the machine for testing.
Testing the punch cycle no faulting occurred then in auto the fault did not occur again.
with the machine back in production it was decided to run for a day and arrange a follow up call to see if the fault has cleared or had reoccurred.
after a days production the fault has not occurred again.

After some discussions setting and testing length and offset parameters.
could not maintain the length accuracy -kept changing.
got them to check the encoder assembly.
The pressure roller was loose.
after removing the coil.
the encoder roller was loose on drive shaft and had moved left all the way to the end of the shaft.
top and bottom roller were not even touching.
have realigned again and running ok again.

In the Frama 5600 that produces the 203.2 millimeter  profiles we have an issue when assembling the panels.
The screw hole of the truck and the screw hole in the stud do not align and so the screw is either placed skewed or they place a screw not in the hole.
You can see in the picture that at the very end of the swage the profile bends out and it seems that the width of the profile is as wide as the profile without the swage.

suggested Sydney remove or try and straighten the spacer ring.
check the wear on bottom roller and may need to replace top roller.

Castle group have been having issues with tooling sticking mainly the end truss and notch not cycling. From discussions yesterday with staff on-site the 150mm profile pre punch block was stripped and tools inspected. The main tools look not to be damaged but the side tools of the end truss and the lip cut tools are chipped and marked. These tools do not have a high tool count. Further discussions were held and Victor shared the mill cert from the last two coil deliveries. i understand that the lip heights should be different on one side then the other, the washer under the lip former on one side causes this. but im still getting to high numbers or differences that dont make sense. or when i do correct the heights to around 35mm or below we end up having a negative result elsewhere when it comes to machine jams, and the material struggling to push through the lip without folding in on it self, or getting no movement errors and having to take the lip off the get the piece to run through( these pieces do have high notch counts and lipcuts which doesn't help the situation when it comes to getting it through the lip)

When Windows installs updates, it drops the new Windows component in the WinSXS folder and keeps the old component in the WinSXS folder. This means that every Windows Update you install increases the size of your WinSXS folder. This allows you to uninstall operating system updates from the Control Panel, which can be useful in the case of a buggy update — but it’s a feature that’s rarely used.

Newton steel have found that the coil loader is too jerky and has a few issues regarding the mechanical operation of the coil loader. The coil loader is still wired up but they will not use it as its 'Too Dangerous” to operate with a full coil. We have moved the cabinet to the side for now and removed the coil guard so they can still load and operate the 5600 by accessing the decoiler from the back with the forklift.
-The rotational speed of the mast is to fast and the sudden start/stop shakes the coil too much.
-The coil loader cannot reach down to a ‘part coil’ (Half Used Coil)
-The mast centre isn't straight/ parallel with the length of the coil loader frame and sits slightly crooked to the decoiler.
-One of the wields in the bottom of the frame hit the trolly wheels as it travels the length of the frame and shakes the coil.
-When advanced all the way to its “out position” (End of frame) it flicks out the cable tray
Some easy fixes that I recommend we look into to make this safer is
-Adding 2x rubber stops to the end of the frame so it won't kick the cable tray out.
-Making a safety bar that locates on a pin and easily removeable so they can quickly secure a coil to the mast without the risk of it falling off
-finding a way to realign the mast
-Slowing the speed of the rotation (clockwise / counter clockwise / In and out)

Stock #0060011i stub roller had come loose, separating from its shaft and falling onto the bottom catch tray.

Question- Do you use an adhesive such as Loctite or similar to secure the roller to the shaft?
The shear moving blade (Stock #0100071fa) can jam if the top two M8 cap screws (Stock #CM8X70) and bottom two cap screws (Stock #CM8x90) are tight.
*Note: Stock #CM8x90 is actually a 80mm long bolt not 90mm long.
To un-jam the blade, one must loosen these four screws (bolts) to allow the blade to be free and slide through the assembly.
It appears that the two side shim plates (Stock # 01000091) are too thin, meaning the gap for the moving blade is too small, and clamps tight, jamming the blade.
I would expect these screws should be tight so they don’t become loose and not allow the assembly halves to separate over time, leaving more gap and allowing cut material to jam between the blades.
Question 1- What should the tolerance be between the moving blade and fixed blades?

Question 2- What are the allowable blade thickness wear tolerances for the moving blade and top infeed blade and top outfeed blade? (I assume both 40mm and 50mm shear assemblies would have the same tolerances?)
Question 3- What torque setting should the four bolts be? The two top and bottom cap screws (bolts)?

Instructions from Andrew for the FRAMA 5600
For the 5600, it’s a little bit complicated since it uses a regular network switch instead of a router.
The customer’s IT team will need to assign a static IP address for the touch screen of this machine.
Afterwards, they will need to modify the following:
Go into the network adapter settings and local the network which uses the static IP address “192.168.10.3”. This should be “Ethernet 2”.
Go into Properties.
Select Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4) Properties.
Click On Advanced…
Click On Add
Have the customer enter the static IP address and subnet mask given by their IT team, then click Add. They should see 2 sets of IP addresses.
Customer may also specify the DNS and gateway for external internet access.
Click on all Oks then that should be done.
CPAC are trying to connect the FRAMA 6800 to their network but are having a few conflicting IP address issues.
Communication from Andrew below.
For the 6800, they will need to connect their ethernet cable from their local area network to the internet port of the IXON router.

The internal IP address of the router was configured incorrectly, they won’t have internet on their touch screen PC until we have made some modification. This can be done during NZ time as long as that cable is in and the machine has remained powered on.
Once the router has been configured correctly, the customer can set the static gateway and DNS server (Figure 2).
